did.unittitle: Records of the Natural History Society of Edinburgh

bioghist.p: Societas Naturae Studiosorum Edinburgena or the Natural History Society of Edinburgh was set up in 1782 with the object of investigating Natural History and Chemistry. The Society was founded by James Edward Smith (1759-1828) and four or five of his friends. It would be 'a society for the prosecution of natural history'. It continued for some thirty years, coming to an end in 1812 when it was absorbed by the Royal Physical Society of Edinburgh which despite its name had a pronounced natural history orientation.

scopecontent.p: The records consist of: a photo-copy of Laws of the Society instituted at Edinburgh for the investigation of Natural History published in Edinburgh by C. Stewart, 1803; and, twelve volumes covering the period 1782 to 1806 containing manuscript accounts of papers read to the Society. Early examples of these include A account of the Capra ibex and Capra Rupicapia read on 12 April 1782, and An essay on collecting and preserving specimens of plants read on 19 April 1782.
